posts.name: Adobo Food Truck
posts.note: From the Denver Eater website, 'Combining Filipino and New Mexican influences with panache, this West Highland newcomer does an equally bang-up job of mixing sweet, spicy, and salty ingredients, be it the succulent chicken spicy pinoy taco topped with green chile, pineapple, and scallion or the smoked carnitas version with lime-fig jam, chicharrones, and cilantro.' Fresh, Fried, and Crispy recommends ordering the Chile cheese fries with smoked potatoes that are then deep fried, cheddar Jack cheese, house-made green hatch chili sauce, Cotija cheese, and lime crema. Or the lumpia (Filipino egg roll), which contains pork should, green onions, carrots, garlic, ginger, oyster sauce, white and black pepper, etc., with doboyaki sauce.

posts.name: Big Mac and Little Lu's Seafood
posts.note: Relaxed, family-run restaurant and grocer with fish on the menu and on display in ice-filled cases. From their website, 'Family-owned restaurant by Paul and his two girls originally from Florida. Bringing in fresh fish daily. Always wild caught, never farm-raised. Never frozen.' Fresh, Fried, and Crispy recommends ordering the blue point fried oyster with horseradish cocktail sauce or the almond-crusted hogfish with Stone Crab mustard sauce on Caribbean rice and a side of veggies.

posts.name: Blue Sparrow Coffee
posts.note: Blue Sparrow Coffee is committed to their neighborhood, the people who work here and live here. They strive to serve you the best coffee in a friendly, comfortable environment. Blue Sparrow Coffee has partnered with local food providers bringing you the highest quality products from Enzo the Baker, Marczyk Fine Foods, and Genova's Biscotti. From their website, 'Located within Denver's thriving River North Arts District and the Platte Street community, we're committed to our neighbors, the people who work and live here. We strive to serve you the best coffee in a friendly, comfortable environment. Over the years, we've made a lot of friends in the coffee world who are dedicated to quality, sustainability, and community. Now is our chance to share their coffees with you.'

posts.name: Buckhorn Exchange Restaurant
posts.note: From their website, 'Denver’s original steakhouse, The Buckhorn Exchange, is located in the city’s oldest neighborhood, just 5-minutes from downtown Denver -- with a light-rail stop right across the street. This National Historic Landmark and Western Museum has been serving the finest in Old West fare since 1893. Prime Grade Beef Steaks, Buffalo, Elk, Colorado Lamb, Fish, Fowl, and Baby Back Pork Ribs are just some of the marvelous offerings on the Buckhorn menu. Exotic appetizers such as rattlesnake and alligator tail are available, and no dinner is complete without the house specialty, Rocky Mountain Oysters.' From the Denver Eater website, 'Because, just once, everybody should visit a landmark established in 1893 to eat elk, bison, and bull testicles while making eye contact with the mounted heads of other elk, bison, and angry-looking bulls.' Fresh, Fried, and Crispy recommend ordering the Rocky Mountain oysters or one of their other exotic meats.

posts.name: Dae Gee Korean BBQ
posts.note: Dae Gee (which means pig in Korean) is a Korean BBQ restaurant progressively blending Korean food tradition with American culture. We combine the freshest ingredients, endless flavor, and a fun atmosphere to give you the exceptional dining experience you deserve. They serve unlimited BBQ along with unlimited sides for both lunch and dinner. From their website, 'Joe Kim loves it when someone comes to one of his Dae Gee Korean BBQ restaurants and truly pigs out. In fact, Dae Gee translates to “pig” in Korean, and “Pig Out” is its unofficial motto. So one of Kim’s favorite customers is Ethan Tsai. “He used to come into our first spot and really pig out,” Kim says. Back then, Kim had only one location in Westminster, and Tsai was still an organic chemistry professor at Metropolitan State University of Denver. Today, however, Kim owns five Dae Gees, with a sixth on the way, and is getting ready to start up a pandemic-inspired food-shipping business, while Tsai has taken his skills and his Ph.D. to Tivoli Brewing, where he is now the director of brewery operations. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Jones Farms Organics - Specialty Potatoes and Grains
posts.note: From their website, 'Jones Farms Organics is a 4th-generation-family-owned organic potato farm located in the beautiful San Luis Valley of Colorado. We are passionate about our nutrient-dense soil and potatoes, and we pride ourselves on the sustainability of our farming practices. Jones Farms Organics believes that farmers can effectively fend off disease by correctly managing the soil biology and balancing the soil chemistry. Although converting from conventional to organic soil is difficult and time-consuming, we have found it to be effective in combating the diseases and weeds once controlled by harmful chemicals.' From the Whole Foods Whole Story website, 'For the family behind Jones Farm Organics in Hooper, CO, it is with the hopes of changing the system of how we produce food, one potato at a time. With a background in science, Michael Jones is always experimenting with and monitoring the soil. Throughout the season, the Joneses will use a combination of techniques like cattle grazing and cover cropping. The Joneses provide potato medleys to Whole Foods Market stores in the Mountain West Region, working closely with regional foragers Kenny Meyer and Darcy Landis.' They are becoming known for the rye that they grow with distillers and beer makers.

posts.name: The Post Chicken and Beer
posts.note: The Post Chicken and Beer is an upbeat, casual spot serving up fried chicken, comfort-food sides, plus local beer, and cocktails. You need to order the fried chicken and the chicken Chicharrones; fried chicken skin served with a pinto bean hummus. From their website, 'We took the time to do our homework and get the best equipment around so that our fried chicken is perfectly juicy and crispy every single time. We start with humanely raised, all-natural chicken, brine it for hours, give it a dip in buttermilk, dredge it in seasoned gluten-free flour, and then pressure fry it to crisp golden perfection. We rest it for a few minutes to let the flavors meld and season it with our spicy goodness shaker. All that love, care, and attention to detail makes our bird simply mouth-wateringly delicious.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Steuben's Food Service
posts.note: Steuben's Food Service is a classic regional American favorite's place, and cocktails make up the menu at this buzzing, retro-style diner. You need to order the fried chicken with mashed potatoes, gravy, and biscuit. From their website, 'Steuben’s is named after a restaurant in Boston that my Great Uncles, Max and Joe, opened in 1945. Steuben’s became a famous Boston restaurant, nightclub, and hotspot from the 1940’s to the 1960’s on Boylston Street. The Vienna Room, The Cave, and The Blue Room were all part of the Steuben’s space and hosted Big Band, Jazz, and Swing groups with The Rat Pack, proms and sweet sixteens, and more. In its prime, Steuben’s was the center of the Boston dining and nightlife scene.'
